summary: This is an NSA report relaying Fidel Castro's statement on President Kennedy's assassination, emphasizing that while Cuba opposes the U.S. system, they do not celebrate the death of an enemy and warning against using the event to promote anti-Soviet and anti-Cuban hysteria.
summary_one_paragraph: On November 27, 1963, the National Security Agency (NSA) issued a report detailing Fidel Castro's reaction to President John F. Kennedy's assassination, as communicated from Havana's Foreign Ministry to the Cuban Embassy in Accra and other diplomatic missions. Castro stated that Cuba does not rejoice in the death of an enemy, despite their opposition to the U.S. system, and cautioned against exploiting the assassination to incite anti-Soviet and anti-Cuban sentiments, warning that such actions could jeopardize international peace and arguing that Kennedyâ€™s death was detrimental to humanity's interests.
title: 2X/0/CUD/T2433-63: CASTRO MAKES STATEMENT ON DEATH OF PRESIDENT
